    Head J (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [13th March, 2003],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head J of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Ong Chit Chung].

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Chandra Mohan K. Nair (Nominated Member): Sir, with your permission, I would like to take the three items, (d), (e) and (f), together.

    The mission statement of the Ministry of Defence is "to enhance Singapore's peace and security, and should deterrence and diplomacy fail, to secure a swift and decisive victory over the aggressor".

    The defence budget for 2003 is over $8 billion and for 2002 it was also over $8 billion. This is a lot of money. It is the largest budget compared to the next Ministry, which I believe is that of Education, having a budget of about $6.5 billion. All of us would like to see this money being available for use for good deeds - I am not saying that the Defence Ministry is not one - including for poor people and retrenched workers during this time of retrenchment and slow

Column: 735

growth in Singapore. But this is not to be. We are aware that the defence of a country is important and money is required for this. However, I ask the Ministry of Defence: do we need to spend so much? Can the sum not be reduced during these difficult times? Would it be dangerously and critically insecure for Singapore if the budget is reduced, even reduced drastically, and if so, why? Please give us the reasons why this sum cannot be reduced. We are all aware of the need to have a deterrent force, fully ready for the worst scenario. However, we have never had a war on major conflict since independence in 1965. The last was in the 1960s during the Indonesian Confrontation. It has been 40 years since then, and we have had peace all along, both in Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia.

    I take it that we are always concerned about, if at all, Malaysia and Indonesia. I take it that there is no real or perceived threat from any other external forces, no other ASEAN country or any other foreign country, except perhaps in today's context, terrorists, depending on how we define this term. There is so much talk about war and terrorism these days. It is all gloom and, added to that, the economic gloom. Why is there so little talk of peace and harmony by our leaders and all the international statesmen and spiritual leaders - if they are speaking about good and peace for the world? Please give it all the prime time airing. And I urge the press, radio and television to report them, instead of months of Bush and Saddam conflict. It may not even be US-Iraq conflict, mind you, and Prime Minister Tony Blair of England, and it may not even be England that wants to go to war.

    Ideally, in my view, all countries should have a Ministry of Peace, and not Ministry of Defence. And Ministers all over the world should make it their primary objective to reduce conflict, reduce build-up of armaments, nuclear weapons or any form of arms build-up and accessories, including war planes, warships, army tanks, artillery and a whole host of weaponry. And that is what causes the

Column: 736

increase in defence budget, is it not? And who benefits economically - the big corporations, manufacturers of armaments, builders of planes, ships, etc, USA, France and the big powers? I am not sure whether Singapore is involved. If so, let us reflect and search our souls.

    Of course, the increase in military personnel in the Army, Air Force and Navy and support administrative staff goes to increase the budget. Hopefully, all the computerisation would reduce the cost but, then, computerisation is expensive too. My guess is that we fear aggression from Malaysia and Indonesia; Malaysia fears Singapore, and Indonesia and perhaps Thailand; Indonesia fears Singapore, Malaysia and perhaps Australia. We all fear each other in our minds. Are these fears real or perceived? Are all the three or four countries that I have talked about and their top military generals and Defence Ministers theorising a lot? Are they being realistic? Am I being realistic?

    Probably since the 1960s, after our independence in 1965, which has been about 37 years, the generals have been harbouring this fear, I believe. In a sense, it makes them all relevant and feel important. There should be a new thinking by political, military, and spiritual leaders, and our citizens should play a greater role in being critical of people who talk about war and conflict. They must justify their actions and remove all the secrecy which does not help at all for either Singapore, Malaysia or Indonesia. Individually, all of us are peace loving. Our Ministers, military generals, defence officials and citizens all want peace and harmony, a decent job and a happy family. That is all we ask for. That must be the same with Malaysia and Indonesia, is it not, and USA, UK and Iraq or any country for that matter? But when individual human beings take on important roles in the institution of government, things strangely change. How come? Please review all our positions and search our souls to do good for Singapore and other nations.

    I therefore urge our Ministry of Defence to initiate this process of creating a Ministry of Peace, and for the United

Column: 737

Nations and the rest of the world to seriously consider and come up with workable solutions. And through this process, defence budgets could be drastically reduced and made available to other Ministries and for the good of our people.

    Mr R. Ravindran (Marine Parade): Sir, MINDEF has always maintained parallel diplomatic communication links with all major defence forces all over the world, in particular with our neighbouring countries. And such excellent diplomatic relation has stood the test of time even during crisis, even with countries such as Malaysia and Indonesia.

    What I would like to ask the Minister for Defence is: what additional steps MINDEF has in place to increase greater defence cooperation and diplomatic communication with the various defence forces, particularly those involving our strategic partners and the neighbouring countries?

    The Chairman: Dr Ong Chit Chung, you can take both cuts together.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung (Jurong): Sir, earlier on, Mr Chandra Mohan asked whether he was realistic. The answer clearly is no. It reminds me of Neville Chamberlain, the Prime Minister of England in the late 1930s. He met up with Hitler and he came back to England and waved a piece of paper and said, "Peace at hand", and immediately after that, Hitler invaded France and other parts of Europe. And Chamberlain lived in shame in history.

    We cannot take peace for granted. To have peace, you must be prepared for war and you must be prepared to take your defences seriously so that with deterrence, peace will prevail. But if you let down your guard, you would have no peace at all because people would take you for an easy ride. And this is what we in Singapore should not do. So we should not be saying out in public about playing down our defences because then, we would be defenceless. To have peace, you must be prepared for war, and with deterrence, war will never occur. That is our best bet for our security.

Column: 738



    Sir, if you look at the new strategic landscape in South-east Asia, we can see that all the more we should give special attention and priority to defence. We face not only conventional threats, but also low intensity conflicts and operations, terrorist attacks and threats. So far, Sir, the SAF has concentrated on conventional threats and operations. Is the SAF able, in these new circumstances, to adapt and reorientate itself to take on both conventional threats and low intensity operations? We want to know whether the SAF is trained well and is ready for it for the new tasks ahead. We know that the SAF trains rigorously here in Singapore as well as in many overseas countries but some, Sir, are still are unaware of the operational readiness and capability of our armed forces.

    Last week, at an informal dialogue session in my constituency, a lady asked me whether SAF soldiers are good in shooting - she goes down to the basic, ie, shooting, although defences and new technology involve more than that - and whether in real combat, our NSmen would be able to take on the regular soldiers of other armed forces. She also wanted to know how our NSmen fare, in comparison with other armed forces, in joint exercises. I assured her, based on my knowledge, that all is well and our troops are well-equipped and well-trained for their tasks. But it is better to hear from the Minister, from the horse's mouth, so to speak, on the state of readiness of our armed forces.

    Sir, the Bali bombings of 12th October 2002 have suggested that regional terrorist organisations are both willing and well able to mount sophisticated attacks on soft targets in the region. It is therefore incumbent upon governments in the region to do their utmost to ensure that every potential target within their territories is hardened so as to deter terrorist attack. Every attack that succeeds will only play into the hands of the terrorists as it would send off a signal to foreign investors that South-east Asia is not safe.

    If foreign investors pull out, the region, which is still recovering from the financial

Column: 739

crisis of 1997/1998, will be in even deeper trouble. Unemployment will continue to be a big problem, especially in the less well-off countries, and this would only prod more restless, embittered young men into the arms of the extremists.

    Thus, while it is certainly important to expand sufficient resources on tightening border and immigration controls, cutting terrorist funding and improving intelligence flow and exchanges between domestic and friendly foreign agencies, it is more important, I believe, to deal with the root cause of terrorism in the region.

    It is also clear that the governments in the region must take care not to engage in any policy behaviour that inadvertently sends out the message that a particular religion, in this case, Islam, is being targeted. Otherwise, some people may become vulnerable to radical appeals suggesting that they have to take up arms to defend their faith. Eradicating the radical terrorist threat will require more than just law enforcement measures. A coordinated strategy integrating enforcement measures, as well as economic, political and ideologically elements, therefore, is needed.

    Sir, on the issue of countering terrorism, the Bali bombings have prodded the Indonesian Government to get off the fence with respect to groups like the JI. It can no longer pretend that the problem with terrorism does not exist in Indonesia and that Indonesians are not involved with the problem.

    Since the attacks in the United States on 11th September 2001, efforts have been increased to coordinate regional and international actions against terrorism in South-east Asia. ASEAN has announced increased cooperation at its annual Ministerial Meeting in July/August 2002. During these meetings, the United States also signed an anti-terrorism agreement with ASEAN members on 30th July.

    In this regard, I wish to ask the Minister whether we have adequate intelligence

Column: 740

cooperation on terrorism with our neighbours. I wish to ask the Minister whether the backbone of JI in the region has been broken, and how successful is our national security secretariat in its work in countering terrorism. Further, I wish to ask the Minister whether SAF is able to deal with terrorist attacks, including chemical and biological attacks.

    Sir, over the years, the SAF has participated in various UN peace-keeping missions. Recently, such peace-keeping missions have become larger and larger in scale. The biggest mission so far is to Timor-Leste or East Timor. Sir, I had the opportunity to visit our troops at our peace-keeping mission in Timor-Leste. I must say that I am impressed with the enthusiasm and commitment of our soldiers and airmen. However, there are reports of outbreaks of violence there. Although this does not presage a general breakdown of the new state, it does remind us that the road to building a viable nation state is an arduous one. In any case, peace-keeping missions are temporary and that sometime in the near future, we should complete our mission in Timor-Leste and bring back our troops. I would therefore ask the Minister whether there are any other plans in the future of sending any other mission under US auspices, and what are the benefits to the SAF and Singapore of such UN peace-keeping missions.

    The Chairman: Mr Sin Boon Ann is not here. Dr Tan.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam):Sir, I thank Members for their pertinent comments and suggestions on the very important subject of defence and security.

    Sir, I will begin with the security environment, a subject that was raised yesterday by Dr Ong Chit Chung, Ms Irene Ng, Mr Sin Boon Ann and Mr Ravindran. The comments and views expressed by the hon. Members reflect how well Singaporeans realise that our security environment is a difficult and uncertain one.

    From global developments, to the regional situation, to our homeland, there

Column: 741

are forces at work which could have a destabilising effect on Singapore's security. At this time of geopolitical flux, we must put enough effort and resources into enhancing our defence, if we do not want to put Singapore's security at risk.

    Sir, there is a general expectation that there will soon be a war in Iraq. Such a war will not only change the face of the Middle East, but it will also have far-reaching ramifications for the whole world. For us, one core issue is that weapons of mass destruction should not be allowed to proliferate.

    A similar danger looms in the Korean Peninsula. Here, it is not just the prospect of a nuclear-armed North Korea but the impact of this on the geopolitical landscape in the whole Asia-Pacific region, as the US, China and Japan respond to developments in the Korean Peninsula.

    These geopolitical developments at the global level will have consequences for the regional security environment and Singapore's strategic interests. We have limited influence on the policies and actions of the big powers. But we can enhance our security by developing cooperative and mutually beneficial relationships with those countries which share common strategic interests with Singapore, as well as by drawing the heavyweight countries into playing a more active and constructive role in multi-lateral forums which can help stabilise the regional security environment, eg, the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF).

    In our region, serious political and economic challenges which have beset some countries have yet to be resolved. Economic problems will take some time to be sorted out, as domestic factors are compounded by external factors such as the US economy and a possible war in the Gulf.

    Political stability will depend, to some extent, on whether or not socio-economic conditions improve. So long as political and economic conditions remain difficult, there is an increased risk of low intensity

Column: 742

conflicts erupting, with consequent destabilising effects on the rest of the region.

    The prospect of elections and leadership transitions could also have an impact on political stability. In Indonesia, there will be a more heated political atmosphere, as parties and presidential aspirants jostle in the run-up to the elections next year. In Malaysia, there has also been talk of early general elections, and there is general expectation of a leadership transition this October.

    Sir, I want to emphasise that Singapore wants good relations with all our neighbours. But we should not be surprised if, at a time of political changes and economic difficulties, there are those who find it politically advantageous to raise the Singapore bogey. We have had some taste of this recently, with attempts to paint Singapore as unreasonable and greedy, accompanied by wild allegations in a media campaign to whip up anti-Singapore feelings. Even the word "war" and the threat of war have been bandied about irresponsibly by some politicians.

    Over the past year-and-a-half, we have also faced the real and present threat of terrorism in our homeland. Singaporeans know how serious the threat is. The arrest of the Jemaah Islamiyah members has dealt a serious blow to the network in Singapore, but terrorism is an enemy we cannot afford to underestimate. The Al Qaeda has not been destroyed. Nor has the Al Qaeda given up its war of terror. We will have to grapple with the threat of terrorism for years to come.

    As Members can see, there are many challenges and uncertainties in our security environment. It is against this background that we have to consider our budget for defence, a subject raised by Dr Ong Chit Chung, Mr Sin Boon Ann, Mr Ravindran and Mr Low Thia Khiang. In these difficult times, Members are naturally concerned that the funds allocated for defence are spent wisely and with care to ensure that we get the maximum value for every dollar spent on defence. I want to assure Members that the Government and the Ministry of

Column: 743

Defence are very conscious of the need to scrutinise carefully every area of our defence spending to ensure that there is no wastage or unnecessary expenditure of our hard-earned funds.

    A word about transparency of defence spending, a subject raised by Mr Low Thia Khiang yesterday. By its very nature, defence procurement and SAF operations are not subjects which can be opened for discussion in public. Doing so will compromise our security. And for this reason, MINDEF has always kept details of its spending secret, and this is the practice in many other countries. This policy has worked and there is no reason to change it.

    Sir, in the context of the security environment, which I have outlined, adequate spending on defence is not an optional priority for the Government. Nor is adequate spending on defence just a desirable objective. For Singapore, adequate spending on defence is an absolute necessity.

    Security is the basic foundation on which we sustain our nationhood and build Singapore's future. Without security, there can be no economic development or political stability. There will be no foreign investments, for who will want to put money in an insecure small country. And, most critically of all, without security, Singaporeans will have no confidence in our future. Simply put, without a strong and credible SAF, there is no Singapore.

    It is in this light that I listened with astonishment to Mr Chandra Mohan's thoughts on defence, military spending and global peace and harmony. Mr Chandra Mohan argues essentially that the less we spend on the military, the greater could be the chances of peace. Sir, the real world is quite different from the rosy picture drawn by Mr Chandra Mohan. The fact of the matter is, no matter how much we may wish it to be so, less military spending does not mean more peace. Adequate defence spending is the insurance premium we have to pay

Column: 744

for peace. We have to invest in defence so that we do not need to go to war.

    There is nothing more tempting to a potential aggressor than a soft and easy target. If we are weak, those who want to impose their will on us may be tempted to go beyond spouting the rhetoric of war to actually try to use military force to subjugate us or prevent us from pursuing our national interests. If we want peace, we have to prepare for war. This is the basis of our policy of deterrence. We best avoid war not by merely advocating love and peace but by deterring those who may have aggressive designs on our security, territorial integrity and national interests. Potential aggressors must know that the cost of any military adventurism against Singapore would be too high for them.

    Sir, let me make one point clear. Singapore is not looking for a fight with anyone. We have put a high priority on developing cooperation and mutually beneficial relations with the countries around us. And we have every interest in seeing our neighbours do well, because an economically thriving and politically stable region is important for Singapore's own security and prosperity.

    Singapore desires friendly and cooperative relations with all countries in our region. But such good relations must be based on the fundamental principle that Singapore is a sovereign nation with our own national interests to safeguard and to promote. Having a credible defence capability ensures that we will not be pushed around. The SAF gives us the space to pursue Singapore's own best interests.

    Sir, the SAF has been systematically built up over more than three decades. Developing a defence capability takes careful, long-term planning and investment. It requires a strong and steady commitment. It is not possible to build up significant defence capabilities at short notice. We cannot develop our military capabilities in a coherent manner and plan and spend prudently if we adopt a feast-and-famine

Column: 745

approach, where we spend only in good years and cut back drastically in bad years.

    Security threats can appear much more quickly than it takes to develop the capability to deal with them. The steady commitment of the Singapore Government to developing our defence capability, and the support which Singaporeans give to this, have not escaped the notice of others. It is as much our military hardware as the commitment of the Government and our people to ensuring Singapore's security that underpin our deterrence policy.

    Sir, deterrence is one pillar of our defence policy. The second pillar is diplomacy, a subject raised by Dr Ong Chit Chung and Mr Ravindran. Singapore desires friendship and cooperation with other countries, particularly those which share common strategic interests with us. MINDEF therefore puts significant efforts into developing defence relations. This pays off in terms of enhancing our security in a number of ways.

    We have interactions with armed forces and defence establishments in our own region and all over the world. These include military exercises, military-to-military as well as policy discussions, interaction programmes at various levels, and cross-attendance of military training courses. The SAF has access to training facilities in about a dozen countries. At the multilateral level, we conduct land, naval and air exercises.

    All these interactions not only help to develop friendship and mutual understanding and confidence, they also offer benefits in terms of the professional development of our servicemen, including our National Servicemen who participate in these exercises.

    Training and exercising with advanced militaries, for example, the various services of the US armed forces, allow the SAF to benchmark itself against the best in the world. The fact that advanced armed forces are keen to expand the scope and complexity of their military

Column: 746

exercises with the SAF, reflects their high regard for the professionalism of the SAF. Our cooperation with foreign armed forces also allows for collaborations in defence technology, and we have had fruitful collaborations with countries such as the US, France, Sweden and Israel.

    Sir, Dr Ong Chit Chung has asked whether MINDEF has enough resources to tackle both conventional military threats and low intensity conflicts or LICs. He has also asked about our efforts to combat terrorism. Dr Ong has zeroed in on the critical issue of security, and that is, the spectrum of threats, and potential threats that face Singapore, has expanded. This is one important reason why we are seeking an increased budget for defence.

    Since 11th September 2001, MINDEF and our other security agencies, as well as non-security agencies which provide expertise to deal with the wide range of LIC and terrorist threats, have been working hard to quickly develop our capabilities to deal with such threats. These are fundamentally different in nature from the security challenges that we have had to tackle in the past. Global catastrophic terrorism, in particular, is a complex threat which impacts on all dimensions of our national life. The target is not just our security, but also our economy and the fabric of our society. And the threat is constant. It is sustained. Our response has to be multi-faceted, and it must be coherent and integrated.

    In counter-terrorism, the effort has to be a multi-agency one, not only because of the multi-dimensional nature of the threat but also because this allows us to maximise our limited national resources. The National Security Secretariat, which is an inter-agency department located in MINDEF to coordinate this effort, has made significant progress in all three areas of prevention, protection and consequence management.

    In the area of prevention, intelligence is critical and we have had good cooperation with our regional countries. One of the most significant results yielded by this cooperation with our neighbours was the

Column: 747

arrest of Mas Selamet Kastari, the leader of the Singapore JI group. The JI here has been crippled after the arrest of its members, but the threat of terrorism has not been eradicated and we cannot afford to be complacent. We have to harden our defences so that we do not offer tempting targets. And all Singaporeans will have to remain alert and vigilant.

    Sir, let me conclude by saying that we are living in uncertain times. Singapore is more vulnerable to the influence of the external environment than most other countries. We now have to grapple with new and more complex threats even as we have to continue to be prepared for conventional threats. The spectrum of threats has expanded and we must have the defence capabilities to deal with the whole range of threats if we want to ensure Singapore's security. The demands on our security apparatus have grown significantly. We have to grapple with more issues. We have to build up more capabilities. We have to develop more systems. We have to conduct more activities. And we have to do all of these within the limits of our manpower, including our National Service resources. These heavier demands on our security system will continue for some time to come, given that the security environment in our region is unlikely to improve significantly for some time.

    Finally, Sir, to reiterate, security is the most basic requirement for our survival and continued success as a nation. The Singapore Armed Forces and our other security agencies must have the hardware and systems, and Singaporeans must have the commitment and resolve to ensure Singapore's security.

    Sir, I have dealt with most of the points raised by Members. The other points will be dealt with by my colleagues in the Defence Ministry.
